thread.title: Meet Rumer Willis' true Blue 'mystery man'
thread.title_full: Meet Rumer Willis' true Blue 'mystery man' - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Meet Rumer Willis' true Blue 'mystery man'
text:
Bruce Glikas/FilmMagic Rumer Willis and Tye Blue celebrate her run as Roxie in "Chicago." Mystery solved — and there wasn't any.
Still, Tye Blue, a savvy producer and Rumer Willis' live-in gay bestie, is hawking their upcoming cabaret show using a knuckleheaded report that called him her "mystery man."
Why not?
"It's a cheeky toss toward the people that wrote that," Blue, 35, tells the Daily News. "There are no mysteries. I'm a very open book."
Nonetheless, promotional material for "Homage" - the name of their Nov. 4 show at Feinstein's/54 Below - notes that Willis shares the stage with "her 'mystery man.'"
It goes on to note that they'll "attempt to explain their journey as nonsexual life partners in song."
"We wanted people to know that we don't take ourselves too seriously," adds Blue, who's toured in "Rent" and "Hair."
The pair's show will feature jazzy standards and more contemporary songs. The set list now includes "Bang Bang," "You Don't Own Me" and Amy Winehouse's "Valerie."
"We're still figuring it out," says Blue, who's sharing an Upper West Side apartment with Willis while she's in New York. Then it's back to their home in Los Angeles.
As head of Willis' Black Sparrow Productions, he's charge of ordering business cards, booking concerts and, he says, "helping her build her brand."
At 27, she's expanding beyond being the daughter of Bruce Willis and Demi Moore.
She's a "Dancing with the Stars" champ as well as Broadway's latest Roxie Hart in "Chicago." She wraps that run on Nov. 1.
They're reprising "Homage" in L.A. Nov. 12 and Nov. 15.
They've been BFFs for a couple years - since meeting while they were both working on a show at Rockwell Table & Stage in California.
"We were coworkers," says Blue, "and she needed an assistant. I was available. And she loved me. What makes it work? It's hard to pinpoint. But we click mentally."
"We're very different," he continues. "I come from a smalltown. She comes from where she comes from - a famous family."
Which led to a different report that described Blue as a phantom love interest.
"There was also an article saying that I was 'Demi's mystery man,'" says Blue. "I was in the audience next to her during 'Dancing with the Stars.'"
Well, that explains it.
jdziemianowicz@nydailynews.com
